title: ONCO 610D1 Fundamentals of Oncology and Cancer Research
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description:
A multidisciplinary approach to the entire spectrum of principles and practice in all fields of oncology, as well as to its research domains, from basic science to clinical and population health sciences. Content areas will include mechanisms of carcinogenesis, tumour pathology, cancer epidemiology, prevention, screening, diagnosis, treatment, psychosocial support, palliative care, global cancer control, and quality of cancer care services. The multidisciplinary nature of cancer research and clinical care and how research findings inform clinical practice
and policymaking in cancer control will be illustrated.
instructor: Fabian, Marc; Henry, Melissa (Fall)

title: ONCO 610D2 Fundamentals of Oncology and Cancer Research
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: For description see ONCO 610D1.
instructor: Fabian, Marc; Henry, Melissa (Winter)

title: ONCO 611 Proteomics for Precision Medicine
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Proteomic applications in medicine, including an introduction to mass spectrometry and related state-of-the-art proteomics techniques, and how these techniques can be used to answer important medical questions using clinical samples. The determination of levels and post-translational modifications of diagnostic/prognostic protein markers, the concentration of protein therapeutics in plasma, the simultaneous imaging of multiple proteins on tissue slices by MALDI-MS, and global proteome and phosphoproteome analyses to study signaling pathways. Additionally, strategies for data analysis and data interpretation using modern bioinformatic tools.
instructor: Borchers, Christoph (Winter)

title: ONCO 615 Principles and Practice of Clinical Trials
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description:
An overview of the design, conduct and analysis of clinical trials. Topics include types of clinical trials, study designs, practical considerations when setting up a
clinical trial, ethics, regulatory requirements, trial monitoring, data management, investigator responsibilities and statistical analysis.
instructor: Agnihotram, Venkata (Fall)

title: ONCO 620 Best Practices in Biomedical Research
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Overview of research ethics as well as best practices and guiding principles in planning, conducting and publishing a research investigation. Topics include (i) ethics in biomedical research, (ii) reading and reviewing papers, (iii)research integrity and (iv) scholarly publishing. Examples will be taken from the field of cancer research. The importance of interdisciplinary collaboration in enhancing the value of biomedical research will be illustrated.
instructor: Franco, Eduardo (Winter)

title: ONCO 625 Quality Improvement Principles and Methods
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Principles and methodology of quality improvement in the delivery of health services with a focus on clinical care in oncology. Topics include developing and conducting quality improvement initiatives, data collection, data analysis and implementation of change in clinical practice.
instructor: Skamene, Sonia (Fall)

title: ONCO 630 Oncology Practicum
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Involvement in a real-world research or quality improvement project with relevance to the students’ chosen area of focus.

title: ONCO 635 Qualitative and Psychosocial Health Research
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: An overview of the theoretical, methodological and analytical skillsets required to design, conduct and analyze qualitative health research studies, with emphasis on psychosocial oncology and palliative care research.
instructor: Pelaez, Sandra (Fall)

title: ONCO 645 Seminars in Global Oncology
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Identification of the challenges and strategies for addressing cancer prevention, diagnosis and care, as  well as cancer research and education from an international perspective.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: ORGB 325 Negotiations and Conflict Resolution
course_description: A conceptual framework to guide participants through negotiation and conflict resolution process.
instructor: Hollister, Matissa (Fall) Westgate, Chantal (Winter)

title: ORGB 330 People Analytics
course_description: This is the era of big data. Companies and organizations are collecting an enormous amount of information and we are only just beginning to grasp the ways in which this information might be used. This course covers the emerging field of people analytics, which involves applying data collection and analysis techniques to improve the management of people within organizations. We will cover current people analytics techniques, common pitfalls, and possible shortcomings of people analytics, as well as the ethical questions involved in undertaking such analyses.
instructor: Hollister, Matissa (Winter)

title: ORGB 380 Cross Cultural Management
course_description: Addresses dilemmas and opportunities that managers experience in international, multicultural environments. Development of conceptual knowledge and behavioural skills (e.g. bridging skills, communication, tolerance of ambiguity, cognitive complexity) relevant to the interaction of different cultures in business and organizational settings, using several methods including research, case studies and experiential learning.
instructor: Gauvin, Tatiana (Fall) Gauvin, Tatiana (Winter)

title: ORGB 401 Leadership Practicum in Social Sector
course_description:
Students apply a wealth of OB concepts and leadership strategies by spending the equivalent of one full day (8 hours) per week at an organization within Montreal’s social sector. Course material will supplement field experiences. The
Practicum complements ORGB 321, which offers a more comprehensive survey of leadership theory.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: ORGB 409 Organizational Research Methods
course_description: Field research in organizational behaviour.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: ORGB 420 Managing Organizational Teams
course_description: Theory, research, and applications. Principles of team processes and effectiveness in organizational settings, specifically the theoretical developments and empirical findings of group dynamics and team effectiveness, and practical strategies and skills for successful management of organizational teams.
instructor: Sonberg, Melissa (Fall)

title: ORGB 421 Managing Organizational Change
course_description: Organizational change theory and techniques are examined with an emphasis on techno-structural interventions such as Quality-of-Work-Life approaches. Through simulations and case-studies, the course explores initiatives in organizational change, primarily in contemporary Canadian organizations. It also includes opportunities for "hands-on" experience in work and organization redesign.
instructor: Saunders, David (Winter)

title: ORGB 434 Topics in Organizational Behaviour 1
course_description: This is an advanced course for students with a special interest in Organizational Behaviour. Topics will be selected from current issues or themes in literature.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: ORGB 440 Career Theory and Development
course_description: Includes state of the art theory and research on careers and opportunity for exploration and development of personal career goals and dreams. Analytical and practical skills are honed through the study of careers of "real life" individuals as presented in films, panels of guest speakers, and interview assignments.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: ORGB 625 Managing Organizational Change
course_description: Examine strategies of organizational development (OD) that enhance the organization's capacity to respond to change, maximize productivity and allow employees to experience dignity and meaning in their work. Explores the strategic, techno-structural, human process, and human resource management types of OD interventions. In addition, the course will provide opportunities for the practice of various OD skills (process consultation, feedback, observation) which enable managers to identify dysfunctional policies or behaviours. The fundamental theoretical framework of the course will draw upon developments in the behavioural and socio-technical systems approaches to organizational change.

title: ORGB 632 Managing Teams in Organizations

title: ORGB 633 Managerial Negotiations
course_description: Negotiating is a critical managerial skill. The purpose of this course is to allow students to learn to be more effective negotiators. The class environment used to accomplish this goal includes many exercises, personality inventories, and cases. The focus of the course will be on the processes of bargaining and the emphasis is "hands on" learning, although theories of negotiation and research examining negotiation will also be covered. Each student will have a great deal of control over how much he or she will develop into a better negotiator as a result of participating in this course.
instructor: Saunders, David (Winter)

title: ORGB 635 Advanced Managerial Negotiations
course_description: This course explores in greater depth the negotiation concepts developed in ORGB 633. instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHAR 540 Advances in Industrial Biotechnology
course_description:
Introduction to emerging technologies and research advances in biotechnologies. Topics include semisynthetic production of drugs and drug candidates through large-scale fermentation, next generation synthesis of DNA and whole genes, green toxicology, single-molecule diagnostics, orphan-drug re-purposing, and next- generation genomic analyses in drug development. Translational research, issues of
entrepreneurship, sustainability, and ethics are also covered.

title: PHAR 565 Epigenetic Drugs and Targets
course_description: This course covers therapeutics targeting epigenetic mechanisms. Although only a handful of epigenetic drugs are in widespread use, further development of such agents is a very active area of research as it has the potential to directly target aberrant gene expression. This course will examine both the current use and potential of epigenetic drugs in treatment of cancer, neurological diseases, immune disorders, and cardiovascular disease. The concept of epigenetics as mediating gene-environment interaction will also be discussed.
instructor: Tanny, Jason (Winter)

title: PHGY 313 Blood, Gastrointestinal, and Immune Systems Physiology
course_description: In-depth presentation of experimental results and hypotheses underlying our current understanding of topics in immunology, blood and fluids, and gastrointestinal physiology.
instructor: Mandl, Judith; Blank, Volker Manfred; Vollrath, Melissa; Fritz, Jörg; Quail, Daniela (Winter)

title: PHGY 314 Integrative Neuroscience
course_description: In depth presentation of experimental results and hypotheses underlying our current understanding of how single neurons and ensembles of neurons encode sensory information, generate movement, and control cognitive functions such as emotion, learning, and memory, during voluntary behaviours.
instructor: Chacron, Maurice; Cook, Erik; Pack, Christopher; Shmuel, Amir; Vollrath, Melissa; Lomber, Stephen; Brandon, Mark; Krishna, Suresh (Fall)

title: PHGY 351 Research Techniques: Physiology
course_description: Provides an overview of common research methods in Physiology, including critical analysis and practical experience with some of the methods. Topics include research ethics of animal experimentation, data analysis, membrane biophysics, radioimmunoassay, ion sensitive dyes, immunocytochemistry, localization techniques, protein transport, cell sorting and molecular biology.
instructor: Lukacs, Gergely; Stochaj, Ursula; Vollrath, Melissa; Nijnik, Anastasia (Winter)

title: PHGY 359D1 Tutorial in Physiology
course_description: The course consists of regularly scheduled meetings between each individual student and a chosen staff member, to consider current problems in biomedical research and to develop background for a research project to be carried out in U3. Brief written summaries of each meeting are required.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHGY 359D2 Tutorial in Physiology
course_description: See PHGY 359D1 for course description.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHGY 396 Undergraduate Research Project
course_description: Independent research project with a final written report.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHGY 419D2 Immunology Research Project
course_description: See PHGY 419D1 for course description.
instructor: Nijnik, Anastasia; Cohen, Monroe W; Mandl, Judith (Winter)

title: PHGY 425 Analyzing Physiological Systems
course_description: An introduction to quantitative analysis of physiological data, both to the mode of thinking and to a set of tools that allows accurate predictions of biological systems. Examples will range from oscillating genetic networks to understanding higher brain function. Modelling and data analysis through examples and exercises will be emphasized.
instructor: Cook, Erik; Glavinovic, Mladen I; Baker, Curtis L; Bashivan, Pouya (Fall)

title: PHGY 451 Advanced Neurophysiology
course_description: Topics of current interest in neurophysiology including the development of neurons and synapses, physiology of ionic channels, presynaptic and postsynaptic events in synaptic transmission and neuronal interactions in CNS function.
instructor: Cooper, Ellis; Cohen, Monroe W; Bourque, Charles W; Chacron, Maurice; Suvrathan, Aparna (Fall)

title: PHGY 459D1 Physiology Seminar
course_description: Discussion of topics in mammalian, cellular and molecular physiology. Students will be required to write one essay and make at least one oral presentation per term. A final course essay is required.
instructor: Hanrahan, John W; Cohen, Monroe W; Shrier, Alvin; White, John H; Lukacs, Gergely; Brown, Claire (Fall)

title: PHGY 459D2 Physiology Seminar
course_description: See PHGY 459D1 for course description.
instructor: Hanrahan, John W; Finnson, Kenneth Walter; Philip, Anie; Shrier, Alvin; Pack, Christopher; Rousseau, Simon; Chen, Brian (Winter)

title: PHGY 461D1 Experimental Physiology
course_description: Individual project work under the supervision of Departmental Staff members.
instructor: Grisaru Wechsler, Ann; Orlowski, John; Vollrath, Melissa (Fall)

title: PHGY 461D2 Experimental Physiology
course_description: See PHGY 461D1 for course description.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHGY 499 Independent Study in Physiology
course_description: Supervised research project in physiology.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHGY 502 Exercise Physiology
course_description: Behaviour of physiological processes in response to physical effort, in areas such as structural basis of muscle contraction, thermoregulation during exercise, mechanics and energetics of muscle contraction, fuel utilization, fatigue, physiological adjustments during exercise and influence of training.
instructor: Rousseau, Simon; Comtois, Alain Steve; Martin, James G; Magder, Sheldon A; Hussain, Sabah N A; Lands, Larry; Petrof, Basil (Winter)

title: PHGY 508 Advanced Renal Physiology
course_description: Advanced concepts in selected areas of kidney physiology, including the glomerulus, renal cell biology, kidney development, membrane and epithelial transport, hormones and autacoids, kidney transplantation, bioengineering and regenerative medicine.
instructor: Cybulsky, Andrey V E; Podymow, Tiina; Alam, Ahsan; Torban, Elena; Takano, Tomoko; Lemay, Serge; Gupta, Indra; Schiffrin, Ernesto L; Unikowsky, Bernard; Hanrahan, John W (Fall)

title: PHGY 513 Translational Immunology
course_description: Advanced key concepts in immunology as they relate to health and disease, including infectious diseases, non-infectious diseases and autoimmunity, and cancer immunology.
instructor: Quail, Daniela; Behr, Marcel A; Rauch, Joyce; Antel, Jack P; Bernard, Nicole F; Schurr, Erwin; Ward, Brian; Fritz, Jörg; Nijnik, Anastasia; Mandl, Judith (Winter)

title: PHGY 515 Blood-Brain Barrier in Health and Disease
course_description: Molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying the organization and regulation of the blood-brain barrier, highlighting neurological diseases associated with the blood-brain barrier breakdown and give an overview of experimental approaches to study blood-brain barrier.
instructor: Prager-Khoutorsky, Maria; Hamel, Edith; Zhang, Ji; Kostikov, Alexey; Rudko, David; Diaz, Roberto; Stratton, Jo Anne (Fall)

title: PHGY 516 Physiology of Blood
course_description: Bone marrow hematopoiesis, with emphasis on regulation of stem cell proliferation and differentiation along hematopoietic pathways. Formation and differentiation of red and white blood cells and some of the diseases associated with hematopoiesis will be covered. Emphasis will be given to the molecular mechanisms involved in the normal and pathological conditions.
instructor: Blank, Volker Manfred; Pantopoulos, Konstantinos; Nijnik, Anastasia (Winter)

title: PHGY 518 Artificial Cells
course_description: Physiology, biotechnology, chemistry and biomedical application of artificial cells, blood substitutes, immobilized enzymes, microorganisms and cells, hemoperfusion, artificial kidneys, and drug delivery systems. PHGY 517 and PHGY 518 when taken together, will give a complete picture of this field. However, the student can select one of these.
instructor: Chang, Thomas Ming Swi (Fall)

title: PHGY 524 Chronobiology
course_description:
An introduction to the field of chronobiology. The aim is to provide basic instruction on different
types of biological rhythms, with particular focus on circadian rhythms.
instructor: Cermakian, Nicolas; Bernard, Daniel; Storch, Kai-Florian (Fall)

title: PHGY 531 Topics in Applied Immunology
course_description: Seminar format course in which experts in immunologic mechanisms of resistance against a variety of infectious diseases, including AIDS, malaria, and tuberculosis oversee student moderators in their presentation of recent scientific literature in the field.
instructor: Bernard, Nicole F; Nguyen, Dao; Ndao, Momar; McCusker, Christine T; Vidal, Silvia; Stevenson, Mary M; Radzioch, Danuta; Qureshi, Salman; Fritz, Jörg; King, Irah (Winter)

title: PHGY 552 Cellular and Molecular Physiology
course_description: Discussions of recent significant advances in our understanding of the gene products involved in diverse cellular signalling pathways. Topics will include cell-surface hormone receptors, nuclear steroid hormone receptors, and ion channels and transporters. Students will present and critically evaluate experimental approaches, results and interpretations of selected research publications.
instructor: Orlowski, John; White, John H; Stochaj, Ursula; Bernard, Daniel (Winter)

title: PHGY 560 Light Microscopy-Life Science
course_description: Introduction to optics, light microscopy imaging and data analysis for life scientists.
instructor: Brown, Claire (Winter)

title: PHIL 198 FYS: Knowledge and Ideas in Early Modern Philosophy
course_description: An introduction to central issues in the philosophy of the early modern period through an examination of works by, for example, Descartes, Malebranche, Spinoza, Locke, Leibniz, Berkeley and Hume.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 199 FYS: Minds, Brain, and Machines
course_description: An introduction to the philosophical foundations of the sciences of the mind.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 201 Introduction to Philosophy 2
course_description: An introduction to some of the major problems of philosophy. This course does not duplicate PHIL 200.
instructor: Gold, Ian Jeffrey (Winter)

title: PHIL 210 Introduction to Deductive Logic 1
course_description: An introduction to propositional and predicate logic; formalization of arguments, truth tables, systems of deduction, elementary metaresults, and related topics.
instructor: Hallett, Michael Frank (Fall)

title: PHIL 221 Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science 2
course_description: A survey of the development of modern science since the Eighteenth Century.
instructor: Tal, Eran (Winter)

title: PHIL 230 Introduction to Moral Philosophy 1
course_description: A survey of a number of historically important and influential theories. Philosophers to be discussed may include Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Bentham, Mill, and Moore.
instructor: Howard, Christopher (Fall)

title: PHIL 237 Contemporary Moral Issues
course_description: An introductory discussion of central ethical questions (the value of persons, or the relationship of rights and utilities, for example) through the investigation of currently disputed social and political issues. Specific issues to be discussed may include pornography and censorship, affirmative action, civil disobedience, punishment, abortion, and euthanasia.
instructor: Leary, Stephanie (Winter)

title: PHIL 240 Political Philosophy 1
course_description: An introduction to contemporary philosophy of politics by concentrating on a number of contested concepts, such as freedom, justice and equality, in contemporary political philosophy and practice.
instructor: Sharp, Hasana (Winter)

title: PHIL 301 Philosophical Fundamentals
course_description: An intensive study of basic philosophical skills; reading, writing, analysis, and argumentation.
instructor: Buckley, R Philip (Fall)

title: PHIL 310 Intermediate Logic
course_description: A second course in Logic. NB. The course will be technical in nature, and some mathematical aptitude is essential. The emphasis is on the expressive properties of standard logical systems, including implications for the philosophy of mathematics. We will study the Completeness of First-Order Logic, then the 'limitative' theorems of Tarski and Gödel.
instructor: Hallett, Michael Frank (Winter)

title: PHIL 311 Philosophy of Mathematics
course_description: This course provides an historically informed introduction to philosophy of mathematics. It gives the student an overview of prominent issues and arguments, to enable her to follow and discuss contemporary research in philosophy of mathematics.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 334 Ethical Theory
course_description: A course focusing on central questions in ethical theory such as the nature of the good and the right and the factors which determine moral rightness and wrongness.
instructor: Howard, Christopher (Winter)

title: PHIL 336 Aesthetics
course_description: An introduction to issues central to aesthetic theory; the nature of aesthetic judgment, perception of the aesthetic object, the nature of the art object.
instructor: Davies, David (Fall)

title: PHIL 341 Philosophy of Science 1
course_description: A discussion of philosophical problems as they arise in the context of scientific practice and enquiry. Such issues as the philosophical presuppositions of the physical and social sciences, the nature of scientific method and its epistemological implications will be addressed.
instructor: Magal, Oran (Fall)

title: PHIL 343 Biomedical Ethics
course_description: An investigation of ethical issues as they arise in the practice of medicine (informed consent, e.g.) or in the application of medical technology (in vitro fertilization, euthanasia, e.g.)
instructor: Hirose, Iwao (Fall)

title: PHIL 344 Medieval and Renaissance Political Theory
course_description: A study of Medieval and Renaissance political theory.
instructor: Levy, Jacob (Winter)

title: PHIL 345 Greek Political Theory
course_description: An examination of the ethical and political theories of ancient Greece, especially those of Plato and Aristotle.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 348 Philosophy of Law 1
course_description: A discussion of the nature of justice and law, and of the relationship between them.
instructor: Stoljar, Natalie (Fall)

title: PHIL 349 Environmental Philosophy
course_description: An introduction to environmental ethics; potentially also such related fields as philosophy of ecology, environmental aesthetics, and/or other philosophical topics demonstrably relevant to environmental issues.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 350 History and Philosophy of Ancient Science
course_description: Topics in ancient pure mathematics (geometry and number theory), "mixed mathematics" (astronomy, music theory, optics, mechanics), and/or natural science (including medicine), studied with a view to philosophical issues raised by the content of ancient science and/or by the logic of scientific argument.
instructor: Menn, Stephen (Fall)

title: PHIL 353 The Presocratic Philosophers
course_description: An examination of the surviving fragments of the presocratic philosophers and schools of philosophy, as well as later reports of their views.
instructor: Lewis, Eric (Fall)

title: PHIL 354 Plato
course_description: An examination of some of the philosophical problems (those in logic, epistemology, metaphysics, and ethics, e.g.) found in a selection of Plato's dialogues.
instructor: Hoffmann, Susan Judith (Fall)

title: PHIL 355 Aristotle
course_description: An examination of selected works by Aristotle. The course considers issues in moral philosophy as well as those found in the logical treatises, the Physics and Metaphysics, and in the philosophy of mind.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 356 Early Medieval Philosophy
course_description: An examination of selected works in the Christian, Islamic and Jewish traditions. Topics in moral and political philosophy, logic and metaphysics, philosophical psychology and epistemology, philosophy of science, and philosophical theology may be discussed.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 360 17th Century Philosophy
course_description: An examination of the work of such seventeenth-century philosophers as Descartes, Hobbes, Gassendi, Malebranche, Leibniz, and the Cambridge Platonists.
instructor: Seggie, Daniel (Fall)

title: PHIL 361 18th Century Philosophy
course_description: A survey of eighteenth century philosophy, especially British philosophy. Attention is given to fundamental metaphysical, epistemological, and moral issues as reflected in the work of such philosophers as Locke, Shaftesbury, Berkeley, Hutcheson, Butler, Hume and Reid.
instructor: Carson, Emily J (Winter)

title: PHIL 366 18th and Early 19th Century German Philosophy
course_description: An examination of the works of such philosophers as Kant, Fichte, Jacobi, Schelling, and Hegel.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 367 19th Century Philosophy
course_description: An examination of the works of such 19th century philosophers as Mach, Helmholtz, Dedekind, Frege, Marx, Kierkegaard, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Mill and Bradley.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHIL 375 Existentialism
course_description: This course will examine the nature of existentialist thought as represented in various philosophical and literary texts. Particular themes to be examined include freedom, alienation, responsibility and choice, and the nature of self.
instructor: Buckley, R Philip (Fall)

title: PHIL 427 Topics in Critical Philosophy of Race
course_description: An advanced discussion of topics in the critical philosophy of race.

course_description: A study of the status of sentences containing moral terms, judgements about moral claims, and the nature of moral facts.

course_description: An advanced discussion of issues in aesthetics.

course_description: A survey of political and moral theory from the Reformation to the French Revolution including Luther, Montaigne, Descartes, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau and Smith.

title: PHTH 201 Sports Medicine Practicum 1
course_description: This course is the first in a series of three courses intended to provide students with a directed, practical experience in pre-event, on-field and post-event sports therapy interventions. Students will be introduced to current concepts in sports medicine. Students will work closely with one of the McGill varsity teams, as well as intra- and interprofessionally with the staff of the McGill Sport Medicine Clinic (including physiotherapists, athletic therapists, physicians, and other allied health-care professionals).
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHTH 202 Sports Medicine Practicum 2
course_description: This course is the second in a series of three courses intended to provide students with a directed, practical experience in pre-event, on-field and post-event sports therapy interventions. Students will continue to build their knowledge on current concepts in sports medicine. Students will work closely with one of the McGill varsity teams, as well as intra- and interprofessionally with the staff of the McGill Sport Medicine Clinic (including physiotherapists, athletic therapists, physicians, and other allied health-care professionals).
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHTH 245 Introduction to Professional Practice 1
course_description: Physical therapy and its domains through promoting health and well-being of individuals across the life span.
instructor: Xenopoulos, Frangiska; Boychuck, Zachary (Fall)

Students will work closely with one of the McGill varsity teams, as well as intra- and interprofessionally with the staff of the McGill Sport Medicine Clinic (including physiotherapists, athletic therapists, physicians, and other allied health-care professionals).
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHTH 440 Clinical Exercise Physiology
course_description: Safe and effective prescription of exercise as a preventive and therapeutic tool in patients suffering from clinical conditions.
instructor: Roig, Marc; Moga, Ana Maria (Fall)

title: PHTH 450 Introduction to PT Clinical Practice
course_description: In this course, students will be introduced to clinical skills applicable to various physiotherapy domains of practice. Through clinical skills laboratories, self-directed learning, and interactive learning sessions, students will be developing observation skills, as well as analyzing normal and common deviant movements. They will also be introduced to the development of hypotheses to explain movement impairment. Throughout the course, emphasis will be put on palpation and patient handling skills.
instructor: Xenopoulos, Frangiska (Winter)

title: PHTH 550 Physical Therapy Orthopedic Management
course_description: Evaluation and treatment in a neuromuscular framework.
instructor: Clavet, Heidi; Boudreau, Mylene (Fall)

title: PHTH 551 Physical Therapy Neurological Rehabilitation
course_description: Principles of neurorehabilitation motor learning and neuroplasticity including assessment and treatment.
instructor: Fung, Joyce; Perez, Claire; Venturini, Adriana; Buhler, Marco (Fall)

title: PHTH 554 PT Cardiorespiratory Rehabilitation
course_description: Introduction to the principles of cardiorespiratory physical therapy. Students will gain the necessary theoretical knowledge pertaining to the pathophysiology of various medical and surgical respiratory conditions as well as the practical skills needed for evaluating and treating such acute and chronic conditions. This course introduces students to the clinical decision making process involved in the planning, implementation and progression of a cardiorespiratory physiotherapy treatment program.
instructor: Spahija, Jadranka (Fall)

title: PHTH 560 Integrated Orthopedic Management
course_description: Assessment and treatment of patients with multiple comorbidities or multiple injuries that require a multidisciplinary approach, integrated intervention strategies, life-style changes, integration into the work force and/or reintegration into the community.
instructor: Pearson, Isabelle; Pollice, Jasmine; Ippersiel, Patrick (Winter)

title: PHTH 561 Integrated Neurological Rehabilitation
course_description: PT assessment and treatment of clients with complex problems and/or multiple handicaps.
instructor: Fung, Joyce; Perez, Claire; Venturini, Adriana (Winter)

title: PHTH 564 Integrated Cardiorespiratory Rehabilitation
course_description:
Building on previously learned knowledge of cardiorespiratory physiotherapy, students will gain conceptual and procedural knowledge and skills for the physiotherapy assessment and management of patients with various cardiovascular and respiratory conditions, patients undergoing lung/heart-lung
transplantation, and critically ill patients managed in the intensive care unit (ICU). This course aims to enhance critical thinking and problem-solving skills in the area of cardiovascular and respiratory physiotherapy through interactive lectures as well as case-based labs run at the McGill Simulation center.
instructor: Spahija, Jadranka; Bertagnolli, Mariane (Winter)

title: PHTH 570 Strategies in Physical Therapy Professional Practice
course_description: Study and analysis of strategies and systems which impact the role of the occupational and physical therapy professional in health service delivery settings. This course includes selected topics on professional competence, healthcare environments and service delivery models, administration and management.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHTH 571 PT Clinical Practicum 1
course_description: A first clinical practicum course.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHTH 572 PT Clinical Practicum 2
course_description: A second clinical practicum including advanced skills in assessment and treatment management in a core area of practice.
instructor: Garnett, Crystal; Visintin, Martha (Winter)

title: PHTH 573 PT Clinical Practicum 3
course_description: Advanced assessment and treatment management in an area of practice.
instructor: Visintin, Martha; Salvo, Lora; Di Re, Antonietta (Fall) Garnett, Crystal; Visintin, Martha; Di Re, Antonietta; Turgeon-Desilets, Sarah (Winter)

title: PHTH 606 Introduction to Pediatric Physical Therapy
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: This course introduces the principles of pediatric habilitation and rehabilitation pertinent to the practice of physical therapy.
instructor: Gagnon, Isabelle; Turgeon-Desilets, Sarah (Fall)

title: PHTH 620 PT Clinical Practicum 4
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Final clinical practicum in an area of practice.
instructor: Visintin, Martha; Salvo, Lora; Di Re, Antonietta (Fall)

title: PHTH 622 Integrated Pain Management
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description:
This M1 entry-level physiotherapy course focuses on understanding and managing
complex and chronic pain conditions. Through lectures, personal reflection, interactive class activities, case study analyses, quizzes, assignments and practical lab activities, students will develop a conceptual framework for approaching the clinical assessment and management of pain and pain-related disability. By the end of the course, students will be ready to apply this framework within clinical settings.
instructor: Wideman, Timothy Howard (Winter)

title: PHTH 623 Differential Diagnosis and Management
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Building on previously learned orthopaedic knowledge, screening for medical conditions and establishing functional differential diagnosis.
instructor: Pollice, Jasmine; Bernier, Julien (Fall)

title: PHTH 633 X-Ray Prescription for Physical Therapy
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Requirements for X-ray prescription described by the Québec Code des Professions (chapter M-9, r. 4).
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHTH 641 Topics in Cardiorespiratory Rehabilitation
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Exploration of new research concepts related to cardiorespiratory rehabilitation outcome measures and treatment techniques used in the management of patients with various medical, surgical, neurological and cardiorespiratory conditions.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHTH 645 Pelvic Floor Rehabilitation
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: This course explores the physiotherapy approach to pelvic floor disorders, with an in-depth focus on urinary incontinence. Students will understand the role of the pelvic floor in relation to urinary, sexual and ano-rectal function, and acquire the ability to evaluate and treat patients suffering urinary incontinence.
instructor: Brown, Claudia (Fall)

title: PHTH 652 Integrated Clinical Exercise Rehabilitation
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: This case-based course aims to provide students with an in-depth knowledge of exercise rehabilitation as a preventative and therapeutic tool in patients with selective chronic diseases and disabilities across the lifespan. This course aims to enhance critical thinking and problem-solving skills through interactive lectures, clinical reasoning workshops and assignments.
instructor: Ferreira, Tania Janaudis (Fall)

title: PHTH 661 Sport Physiotherapy
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Injury prevention for recreational and elite athletes and rehabilitation of injured athletes.
instructor: Pearson, Isabelle (Fall)

title: PHTH 662 Advanced Manual Therapy
faculty: Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences
course_description: Use of manual therapy in the assessment and treatment of patients with musculoskeletal disorders.
instructor: Bernier, Julien; Pollice, Jasmine (Winter)

title: PHWR 300 Philosophy and Western Religions 1
course_description: Introduction to the encounter between philosophy and the Abrahamic religions, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, from Antiquity to the 12th Century, covering the philosophical sources (Plato to Neoplatonism), the religious sources (Bible to Qu'ran), and their manifold syntheses in the thought of theologians, philosophers and mystics within the three religious traditions.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHWR 301 Philosophy and Western Religions 2
course_description: Introduction to the encounter between philosophy and the three Abrahamic religions, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, from the 13th Century to the Enlightenment, covering the manifold syntheses of philosophical and religious ideas in thinkers from the Later Middle Ages, the Renaissance, the 17th Century and the Enlightenment.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHWR 400 Joint Honours/Honours Tutorial
course_description: Guided reading and research for Joint Honours and Honours students in their final year.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHWR 402 Honours Thesis Tutorial 2
course_description: Final guided reading and research for Honours students in their final year.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHWR 500D2 Interdisciplinary Seminar
course_description: See PHWR 500D1 for course description.

title: PHYS 101 Introductory Physics - Mechanics
course_description: An introductory course in physics without calculus, covering mechanics (kinematics, dynamics, energy, and rotational motion), oscillations and waves, sound, light, and wave optics.
instructor: Caron-Huot, Simon (Fall)

title: PHYS 102 Introductory Physics - Electromagnetism
course_description: Electric field and potential. D.C. circuits and measurements. Capacitance. Magnetic field and induction. Electromagnetic waves and geometrical optics.
instructor: Provatas, Nikolaos (Winter)

title: PHYS 117 Mechanics Laboratory
course_description: The laboratory component of PHYS 131.
instructor: Pereg-Barnea, Tami (Fall)

title: PHYS 118 E & M Laboratory
course_description: The laboratory component of PHYS 142.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 131 Mechanics and Waves
course_description: The basic laws and principles of Newtonian mechanics; oscillations, waves, and wave optics.
instructor: Pereg-Barnea, Tami (Fall)

title: PHYS 142 Electromagnetism and Optics
course_description: The basic laws of electricity and magnetism; geometrical optics.
instructor: Guo, Hong (Winter)

title: PHYS 180 Space, Time and Matter
course_description: A nonmathematical, conceptual look at physics, beginning with the idea of space and time, continuing with the historical development of Newtonian mechanics of celestial motion, electricity and magnetism, ether and light, Einstein's special and general theories of relativity, quantum mechanics, matter and antimatter, cosmology and the big bang.
instructor: Brandenberger, Robert (Fall)

title: PHYS 181 Everyday Physics
course_description: The day-to-day physics behind the materials and phenomena around us. Demonstrations of the intriguing properties of materials and the simple physical theories explaining them.
instructor: Kaspi, Victoria (Winter)

title: PHYS 182 Our Evolving Universe
course_description: An elementary course on astronomy and astrophysics. Positional astronomy and finding your way about the sky. Our evolving picture of the universe. Properties and origins of the solar system. The Big Bang and modern cosmology.
instructor: Dobbs, Matthew Adam (Fall)

title: PHYS 183 The Milky Way Inside and Out
course_description: An elementary course on astronomy. Star origins and star formation, supernovae, white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Galaxies, their structure and their interactions. Stellar clusters, the interstellar medium. Galactic classification and galaxy evolution.
instructor: Webb, Tracy (Winter)

title: PHYS 184 Energy and the Environment
course_description: Energy fundamentals, generation of electricity, heat engines, fossil fuel production and consumption, local and global effects, economic impact, transportation, and pollution and environmental impact of energy use. Non-renewable energy sources (fossil fuels, nuclear) and renewable sources (solar, wind, hydro, geothermal).
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 186 Astrobiology
course_description: Astrobiology is the study of life throughout the universe. The course will cover the search for, and characterization of, habitable worlds. We will explore the formation and evolution of stars and planets, the astronomical and geological factors that impact a planet's habitability, the evolution of life on Earth, and the potential for biological evolution beyond an organism's planet of origin.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 224 Physics of Music
course_description: An introduction to the physics of music. Properties of sound and their perception as pitch, loudness, and timbre. Dissonance, consonance, and musical intervals and tuning. Physics of sound propagation and reflection. Resonance. Acoustic properties of pipes, strings, bars, and membranes, and sound production in wind, string, and percussion instruments. The human voice. Room reverberation and acoustics. Directional characteristics of sound sources.
instructor: Sankey (Childress), Jack (Fall)

title: PHYS 228 Energy and the Environment
course_description: Energy fundamentals, generation of electricity, heat engines, fossil fuel production and consumption, local and global effects, economic impact, transportation, and pollution and environmental impact of energy use. Non-renewable energy sources (fossil fuels, nuclear) and renewable sources (solar, wind, hydro, geothermal).
instructor: Lovejoy, Shaun MacDonald (Winter)

title: PHYS 230 Dynamics of Simple Systems
course_description: Translational motion under Newton's laws; forces, momentum, work/energy theorem. Special relativity; Lorentz transforms, relativistic mechanics, mass/energy equivalence. Topics in rotational dynamics. Noninertial frames.
instructor: Guo, Hong (Fall)

title: PHYS 232 Heat and Waves
course_description: The laws of thermodynamics and their consequences. Thermodynamics of P-V-T systems and simple heat engines. Free, driven, and damped harmonic oscillators. Coupled systems and normal modes. Fourier methods. Wave motion and dispersion. The wave equation.
instructor: Hilke, Michael (Winter)

title: PHYS 241 Signal Processing
course_description: Linear circuit elements, resonance, network theorems, diodes, transistors, amplifiers, feedback, integrated circuits.
instructor: Reisner, Walter (Winter)

title: PHYS 242 Electricity and Magnetism
course_description: Properties of electromagnetic fields, dipole and quadropole fields and their interactions, chemical binding of molecules, electromagnetic properties of materials, Maxwell's equations and properties of electromagnetic waves, propagation of waves in media.
instructor: Rutledge, Robert (Fall)

title: PHYS 251 Honours Classical Mechanics 1
course_description: Newton's laws, work energy, angular momentum. Harmonic oscillator, forced oscillations. Inertial forces, rotating frames. Central forces, centre of mass, planetary orbits, Kepler's laws.
instructor: Gale, Charles (Fall)

title: PHYS 253 Thermal Physics
course_description: Energy, work, heat; first law. Temperature, entropy; second law. Absolute zero; third law. Equilibrium, equations of state, gases, liquids, solids, magnets; phase transitions.
instructor: Grutter, Peter H (Fall)

title: PHYS 257 Experimental Methods 1
course_description: Introductory laboratory work and data analysis as related to mechanics, optics and thermodynamics. Introduction to computers as they are employed for laboratory work, for data analysis and for numerical computation. Previous experience with computers is an asset, but is not required.
instructor: Vachon, Brigitte (Fall)

title: PHYS 258 Experimental Methods 2
course_description: Advanced laboratory work and data analysis as related to mechanics, optics and thermodynamics. Computers will be employed routinely for data analysis and for numerical computation, and, particularly, to facilitate the use of Fourier methods.
instructor: Cooke, David (Winter)

title: PHYS 271 Introduction to Quantum Physics
course_description: The observed properties of atoms and radiation from atoms. Electron waves. The Schroedinger Equation in one dimension. Quantum mechanics of the hydrogen atom. Angular momentum and spin. Quantum mechanics of many electron systems. Basic ideas of electrons in solids and solid state physics.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 319 Introduction to Biophysics
course_description: Emerging physical approaches and quantitative measurement techniques are providing new insights into longstanding biological questions. This course will present underlying physical theory, quantitative measurement techniques, and significant findings in molecular and cellular biophysics. Principles covered include Brownian motion, low Reynolds-number environments, forces relevant to cells and molecules, chemical potentials, and free energies. These principles are applied to enzymes as molecular machines, membranes, DNA, and RNA.
instructor: Reisner, Walter (Winter)

title: PHYS 320 Introductory Astrophysics
course_description: A survey of astrophysics ranging from stars and planets, to compact objects, galaxies, and the large-scale evolution of the Universe. A calculusbased course, with a focus on simple mathematical derivations that capture the essential physics.
instructor: Schutz, Katelin (Fall)

title: PHYS 321 Data Science and Observational Astrophysics
course_description:
Data analysis methods as applied in experimental physics, with an emphasis on applications in observational astrophysics. An introduction to Bayesian
inference, model selection, Markov Chain Monte Carlo, common probability distributions, jackknives and null tests, as they are used in the analysis of observational data from across the electromagnetic spectrum.
instructor: Webb, Tracy (Winter)

title: PHYS 328 Electronics
course_description: Semiconductor devices, basic transistor circuits, operational amplifiers, combinatorial and sequential logic, integrated circuits, analogue to digital converters. The laboratory component covers design, construction and testing of basic electronic circuits.
instructor: Hanna, David (Fall)

title: PHYS 329 Statistical Physics with Biophysical Applications
course_description: This interdisciplinary course introduces Statistical Physics illustrated with modern biophysical applications. Principles covered include partition functions, Boltzmann distribution, bosons, fermions, Bose Einstein condensates, Ferni gases, chemical potential, thermodynamical forces, biochemical kinetics, and an introduction to noise and phase transitions in biology.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 331 Topics in Classical Mechanics
course_description: Forced and damped oscillators, Newtonian mechanics in three dimensions, rotational motion, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics, small vibrations, normal modes. Nonlinear dynamics and chaos.
instructor: Gervais, Guillaume (Winter)

title: PHYS 333 Thermal and Statistical Physics
course_description: Introductory equilibrium statistical mechanics. Quantum states, probabilities, ensemble averages. Entropy, temperature, Boltzmann factor, chemical potential. Photons and phonons. Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions; applications.
instructor: Rutledge, Robert (Winter)

title: PHYS 339 Measurements Laboratory in General Physics
course_description: Introduction to modern techniques of measurement. The use of computers in performing and analysing experiments. Data reduction, statistical methods, report writing. Extensive use of computers is made in this laboratory; therefore some familiarity with computers and computing is an advantage.
instructor: Ryan, Dominic (Winter)

title: PHYS 340 Majors Electricity and Magnetism
course_description: The electrostatic field and scalar potential. Dielectric properties of matter. Energy in the electrostatic field. Methods for solving problems in electrostatics. The magnetic field. Induction and inductance. Energy in the magnetic field. Magnetic properties of matter. Maxwell's equations. The dipole approximation.
instructor: Lovejoy, Shaun MacDonald (Fall)

title: PHYS 342 Majors Electromagnetic Waves
course_description: Maxwell's equations. The wave equation. The electromagnetic wave, reflection, refraction, polarization. Guided waves. Transmission lines and wave guides. Vector potential. Radiation. The elemental dipole; the half-wave dipole; vertical dipole; folded dipoles; Yagi antennas. Accelerating charged particles.
instructor: Gervais, Guillaume (Winter)

title: PHYS 346 Majors Quantum Physics
course_description: De Broglie waves, Bohr atom. Schroedinger equation, wave functions, observables. One dimensional potentials. Schroedinger equation in three dimensions. Angular momentum, hydrogen atom. Spin, experimental consequences.
instructor: Vachon, Brigitte (Fall)

title: PHYS 350 Honours Electricity and Magnetism
course_description: Fundamental laws of electric and magnetic fields in both integral and differential form.
instructor: Lee, Eve J (Fall)

title: PHYS 351 Honours Classical Mechanics 2
course_description: Rigid bodies, angular momentum, gyroscope, moment of inertia, principal axes, Euler's equations. Coupled oscillations and normal modes. Lagrangian mechanics and applications. Hamiltonian mechanics. Topics in advanced analytical mechanics.
instructor: Schutz, Katelin (Winter)

title: PHYS 352 Honours Electromagnetic Waves
course_description: Vector and scalar potentials; plane waves in homogeneous media; refraction and reflection; guided waves; radiation from simple systems; dipole and quadrupole radiation; introduction to fields of moving charges; synchrotron radiation; Bremsstrahlung.
instructor: Siwick, Bradley (Fall)

title: PHYS 359 Advanced Physics Laboratory 1
course_description: Advanced level experiments in physics including quantum effects and some properties of condensed matter physics and modern physics.
instructor: Ryan, Dominic (Winter)

title: PHYS 362 Statistical Mechanics
course_description: Quantum states and ensemble averages. Fermi-Dirac, Bose-Einstein and Boltzmann distribution functions and their applications.
instructor: Liu, Adrian (Winter)

title: PHYS 396 Undergraduate Research Project
course_description: Independent research project with a final written report.
instructor: Pereg-Barnea, Tami (Fall) Pereg-Barnea, Tami (Winter)

title: PHYS 404 Climate Physics
course_description: This course covers the essentials of climate physics through the lens of one-dimensional, vertical atmospheric models. This includes shortwave and longwave radiative transfer, convection, phase changes, clouds, greenhouse gases, and atmospheric escape. This is an adequate level of detail for understanding Earth's climate, paleoclimate, anthropogenic climate change, or pursing studies of Solar System planets and extrasolar planets.
instructor: Huang, Yi (Fall)

title: PHYS 413 Physical Basis of Physiology
course_description: Analytic and computer simulation techniques are used to examine the role of nonlinearities and time delays in determining the dynamic behaviour of physiological control systems and their relation to normal and pathophysiological states. Examples drawn from the control of respiration, cellular proliferation and differentiation, biochemical feedback networks, thermoregulatory mechanisms, and neural feedback.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 432 Physics of Fluids
course_description: The physical properties of fluids. The kinematics and dynamics of flow. The effects of viscosity and turbulence. Applications of fluid mechanics in biophysics, geophysics and engineering.
instructor: Lee, Eve J (Winter)

title: PHYS 434 Optics
course_description: Fundamental concepts of optics, including applications and modern developments. Light propagation in media; geometric optics and optical instruments; polarization and coherence properties of light; interference and interferometry; diffraction theory and applications in spectrometry and imaging; Gaussian beams, Fourier optics and photonic band structure. A laboratory component provides hands-on experience in optical setup design, construction and testing of concepts introduced in lectures.
instructor: Wang, Kai (Fall)

title: PHYS 439 Majors Laboratory in Modern Physics
course_description: Advanced level experiments in modern physics stressing quantum effects and some properties of condensed matter.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 447 Applications of Quantum Mechanics
course_description: One electron atoms, radiation, multielectron atoms, molecular bonds. Selected topics from condensed matter, nuclear and elementary particle physics.
instructor: Wang, Kai (Winter)

title: PHYS 449 Majors Research Project
course_description: A supervised research project.
instructor: Hanna, David (Fall) Childress, Lilian (Winter)

title: PHYS 457 Honours Quantum Physics 2
course_description: Angular momentum and spin operators. Operator methods in quantum mechanics. Coupling of spin and angular momenta. Variational principles and elements of time dependent perturbation theory (the Golden Rule). Solution of the Schrodinger equation in three dimensions. Applications to the hydrogen and helium atoms and to simple problems in atomic and molecular physics.
instructor: Cumming, Andrew (Winter)

title: PHYS 459D1 Honours Research Thesis
course_description: Honours supervised research project and thesis.
instructor: Gale, Charles (Fall)

title: PHYS 459D2 Honours Research Thesis

title: PHYS 469 Advanced Physics Laboratory 2
course_description: Advanced level experiments in physics including quantum effects and some properties of condensed matter physics and modern physics.
instructor: Sankey (Childress), Jack (Fall)

title: PHYS 478 Short Research Project
course_description: Supervised research project in physics.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 479 Physics Research Project
course_description: A supervised research project.
instructor: Hanna, David (Fall) Childress, Lilian (Winter)

title: PHYS 489 Special Project
course_description: A project incorporating aspects of both physics and computer science, under the joint supervision of the two departments. The Physics aspect may be either laboratory-based or theoretical in nature. The Computational aspect will involve the development and implementation of algorithms arising from the investigation.
instructor: Childress, Lilian (Winter)

title: PHYS 512 Computational Physics with Applications
course_description: Computational methods in Physics illustrated with realworld applications.
instructor: Cumming, Andrew (Fall)

title: PHYS 514 General Relativity
course_description: Transition from special to general relativity. Non-Euclidian geometry. The basic laws of Physics in co-variant form, Einstein's equations. Gravitational waves; neutron stars; black holes; cosmology.
instructor: Maloney, Alexander (Winter)

title: PHYS 519 Advanced Biophysics
course_description: An advanced biophysics course, with a special emphasis on stochastic and out of equilibrium physical processes in living matter.
instructor: Wiseman, Paul (Winter)

title: PHYS 521 Astrophysics
course_description: An advanced course in modern astrophysics, covering topics such as the basic tools of astronomy (statistics, mathematical methods, computational tools, and instrumentation); stellar astrophysics (properties, structure, atmospheres, binaries/exoplanets); the interstellar medium, star formation, stellar evolution and endpoints (white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes); and the Milky Way, galaxies, and cosmology.
instructor: Rutledge, Robert (Fall)

title: PHYS 534 Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
course_description: Topics include scanning probe microscopy, chemical self-assembly, computer modelling, and microfabrication/micromachining.
instructor: Grutter, Peter H (Fall)

title: PHYS 551 Quantum Theory
course_description: General formulation, scattering theory, WKBJ approximation, time-dependent perturbation, theory and applications, angular momentum, relativistic wave equations.
instructor: Jeon, Sang Yong (Fall)

title: PHYS 557 Nuclear Physics
course_description: General nuclear properties, nucleon-nucleon interaction and scattering theory, radioactivity, nuclear models, nuclear reactions.
instructor: Brunner, Thomas (Fall)

title: PHYS 558 Solid State Physics
course_description: Properties of crystals; free electron model, band structure; metals, insulators and semi-conductors; phonons; magnetism; selected additional topics in solid-state (e.g. ferroelectrics, elementary transport theory).
instructor: Coish, Bill (Fall)

title: PHYS 559 Advanced Statistical Mechanics
course_description: Scattering and structure factors. Review of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics; correlation functions (static); mean field theory; critical phenomena; broken symmetry; fluctuations, roughening.
instructor: Coish, Bill (Fall)

title: PHYS 562 Electromagnetic Theory
course_description: Electrostatics, dielectrics, magnetostatics, timevarying fields, relativity, radiating systems, fields of moving charges.
instructor: Cooke, David (Winter)

title: PHYS 567 Particle Physics
course_description: Survey of elementary particles; hadrons, leptons and hadrons' constituents (quarks). Invariance principles and conservation laws. Detectors and accelerators. Phenomenology of strong, electromagnetic and weak interactions.
instructor: Dobbs, Matthew Adam (Winter)

title: PHYS 606 Selected Topics: Contemporary Physics 1
course_description: Selected topics in contemporary physics.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 607 Selected Topics: Contemporary Physics 2
course_description: Selected topics in contemporary physics.
instructor: Liu, Adrian (Winter)

title: PHYS 610 Quantum Field Theory 1
course_description: Relativistic wave equations for spin-0, spin-1/2, and spin-1 particles. Review of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formalisms for classical mechanics. Canonical, Feynman path-integral, and Schwinger external-source quantization techniques. Relativistic quantum field theories for free spin-0, spin-1/2, and spin-1 particles. Interactions, perturbation theory, and Feynman diagrams.
instructor: Brandenberger, Robert (Fall)

title: PHYS 620 Experimental Methods of Subatomic Physics
course_description: Basic techniques of experimentation in nuclear and particle physics. Accelerators, beam optics, detection systems, major experiments, Monte-Carlo simulation, data acquisition and data analysis.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 632 Seminar in  Astrophysics 1
course_description: Seminar on special topics in astrophysics.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 633 Seminar in Astrophysics 2
course_description: Seminar on special topics in astrophysics.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 634 Seminar in Advanced Materials
course_description: A series of research-level seminars about topics of current interest in advanced materials. Topics include molecular and nanoelectronics, computational approaches to materials design and property predictions, new techniques in molecular and atomic imaging, advances in materials preparation, quantum device and quantum computing.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 641 Observational Techniques of Modern Astrophysics
course_description: Mechanical, electrical, optical, and analytic techniques used in modern astrophysics research.  Electromagnetic, gravitational and particle-based observing.  Relevant and topical observational problems, contact with forefront of observational research.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 642 Radiative Processes in Astrophysics
course_description: Why astrophysical sources look the way they do, and how to understand why we see what we see in astronomy.  Fundamental physical processes that produce and modify radiation from astrophysical sources, and how they apply to different astronomical examples.
instructor: Haggard, Daryl (Winter)

title: PHYS 643 Astrophysical Fluids
course_description: Physics of astrophysical fluids; how it determines the behaviour, formation, evolution, dissipation and death of astrophysical systems, including objects in hydrostatic balance, such as stars, or with inflows and outflows, such as disks and jets.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 644 Galaxies and Cosmology
course_description: Our current understanding of the universe, and tools that are used in developing this understanding.  Large scale properties of galaxies in a cosmological context; the most important features of the expanding universe.
instructor: Liu, Adrian; Kaspi, Victoria; Schutz, Katelin (Fall)

title: PHYS 645 High Energy Astrophysics
course_description: Physical bases for phenomena associated with strong gravity and high-energy processes in astrophysical contexts. X-rays, gamma-rays, nuclear processes, strong gravity and magnetic fields. Shocks, acceleration, and jets.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.

title: PHYS 659 Experimental Condensed Matter
course_description: To obtain an active understanding of the principles, the possibilities and the limitations of various experimental techniques. Possible topics include vacuum and low-temperature techniques; transport, thermal, magnetization and de Haas van Alphen measurements; scattering techniques; Mossbauer spectroscopy, NMR, scanning probe microscopy, electron microscopy; surface science methods.
instructor: Childress, Lilian (Winter)

title: PHYS 673 Quantum Field Theory 2
course_description: Loop diagrams, renormalization, Abelian and nonabelian gauge theory, QCD, introduction to the Standard Model.
instructor: Caron-Huot, Simon (Winter)

course_description: Independent work under the direction of the student's supervisor on a research problem in the student's designated area of research leading to a project report or seminar.

course_description: Independent work under the direction of the student's supervisor on a research problem in the student's designated area of research leading to a project report or seminar.

title: PHYS 717 Many-body Physics
course_description: Real-time and imaginary-time Green functions; Diagrammatic perturbation theory; Quantum linear response and Kubo formulae; Path-integral techniques; Fermi gas; Impurity averaging; Interacting electron gas; Magnetism; Phonons & electron-phonon interaction; Superconductivity; Luttinger liquids
instructor: Coish, Bill (Winter)

title: PHYS 718 Special Topics: Solid State Physics 1
course_description: Specialized discussion of some current problems in solid state physics.
instructor: Gervais, Guillaume (Fall)

course_description: Specialized discussion of some current problems in solid state physics.
instructor: Grutter, Peter H (Winter)

course_description: Specialized discussion of some current problems in nuclear physics.
instructor: There are no professors associated with this course for the 2023-2024 academic year.
